dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A media and spectator circus. Two cocky LAPD detectives, ARRANGO and WALTERS, watch as FBI profiler TERRY McCALEB strides past the police barricades. Wearing a blue FBI jacket, the hoary veteran ignores questions shouted out by the press. The words "Code Killer" feature prominently.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: (disparaging) McCaleb... Whatever happens, it’s his face on the front page. As McCaleb reaches Arrango: McCALEB What do you got?

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Fucking hemorrhoids. What are you gonna do about it? Arrango’s itching for trouble. Walters is a cooler head.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: Victims five and six. The code killer strikes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dingy, dark place. Police work lights can’t quite cut the gloom. McCaleb stops at the door with Walters and Arrango. The door is half off its hinges.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: Neighbor came over to complain about the noise. Got run over at the door. Didn’t see a thing.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: We’re calling him Chuck Taylor. McCALEB How’s that? Arrango points out a series of bloody sneaker prints on the floor. Headed for the door and away down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Converse hi-tops. Chuck Taylor. Get it? A look and McCaleb continues in past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for the faint of heart. There are several darkened forms on the floor. Heavy, black plastic bags. An investigative team works.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: We got the remains of two, maybe even three people.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Gives new meaning to the term gang bang. Gruff, desensitized laughs from the cops. Walters motions McCaleb to a wall. There, written in blood: McCaleb, Catch me if you can. 903 472 568.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrango winks at his partner, then, to McCaleb:

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Another love note. The two of you should get a room some place. As McCaleb stares grimly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb exits. The crowd has doubled. A NEWS CREW bursts past the barricade. Police rush to block them, but to no avail. They nearly ring McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS
dialogues.text: Was another message left for you, Agent McCaleb!? -- Why do you think the killer has picked you?! -- What do the numbers mean?! McCaleb scans the sea of humanity before him. Not exactly its best face. With a sigh, McCaleb starts to make his way through, then stops short. Ahead:

dialogues.speaker: FACE IN CROWD
dialogues.text: Seen for an instant. Wearing a hooded sweatshirt and low-billed cap. Staring at McCaleb, an odd look in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat before McCaleb looks downward. THROUGH a thicket of legs, we spot his feet. Covering them are bloody Converse hi-tops. Chuck Taylor. McCaleb looks over, but the cops seem suddenly so far away. Hi-Top begins to drift back. McCALEB (toward cops) Hey... Hey! Over here! Hi-Top turns and goes, suddenly swallowed up by the crowd. McCALEB (to no avail) He’s over here! No one listens. The Reporters continue to fire questions. Hi-Top is getting away. McCaleb fights his way through, charges down the street after him.

dialogues.speaker: STREET 7
dialogues.text: Running now, his face unclear as high-top looks back over his shoulder, sees that McCaleb is chasing him.

dialogues.speaker: NARROW ALLEY 8
dialogues.text: Hi-Top cuts down. McCaleb closes. At the end of the alley, an eight feet redwood fence. Hi-Top jumps, catches hold. As he pulls himself up, McCaleb hits the fence right behind him. The fence collapses. The two men sprawl to the ground. Hi-Top gets up, scoots away. McCaleb rolls to his feet; the chase is back on.

dialogues.speaker: BACK YARDS 9
dialogues.text: One after the next. Fences are scaled, kicked through. And McCaleb closes. All we hear are the FOOTFALLS, the RAGGED BREATHS of the two men. Then... a HEARTBEAT. McCaleb reaches for Hi-Top’s shoulder, inches away now. A chain link fence looms ahead. Hi-Top leaps onto it, catches hold. As he pulls himself up, McCaleb is right behind. He catches hold of one of Hi-Top’s legs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hi-Top grips the top of the fence, rears back with his free leg and kicks McCaleb in the face. McCaleb drops. Hi-Top is up and over, dropping to the other side. An alley behind some businesses. McCaleb gets to his feet, one of Hi-Top’s bloody sneakers in his hands. He starts to climb the fence. The HEARTBEAT INTENSIFIES. McCaleb pauses at the top of the fence, slides back down the way he came. He clutches at his left arm, a look of surprise on his face. The heartbeat eclipses all else. McCaleb is having a heart attack. He grips the fence to keep from falling.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIN LINK 10
dialogues.text: Suddenly, through the pain, McCaleb is aware of a form in the gloom. We don’t see his face, but, fascinated, Hi-Top has come back to watch. McCaleb reaches into his jacket, seemingly for his chest. But when his hand comes back out, he’s holding his .38 service revolver. Blinking against near blinding pain, he aims through the fence. Hi-Top runs for the dark as ROUND AFTER ROUND EXPLODES. The fourth sends him sprawling. The fifth and sixth sail wide as Hi-Top stands and staggers into blackness. McCALEB 121 Suddenly illuminated by a spotlight. The revolver slips from his hand as the pain overwhelms him. Bleached white, he falls back into the dirt, his eyes wide. As he stares up at a silent, hovering LAPD helicopter, he mouths words we cannot understand. And as the HEARTBEAT BECOMES an ELECTRONIC BLIP...

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR SCREEN 12
dialogues.text: A grainy silver and black image of a heart: undulating and ghostly. The snaking line of a scope moves toward it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Almost there.  13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a gurney, his oddly-angled head in a brace, McCaleb closes his eyes as the line enters his heart. The voice belongs to DR. BONNIE FOX, the cardiologist who guides the line through an incision in McCaleb’s neck.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Coming out, Terry. You did good. Removing the scope, she tapes a gauze compress to his neck. As she unstraps the brace, McCaleb rubs his neck. He looks less than formidable in his hospital johnny.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Been taking your pills every day? McCALEB All thirty-four of them.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: No fever at all? McCALEB No, I’m clean.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: And no diarrhea? McCALEB I’m clean of that, too.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Good. Blood pressure and pulse? McCALEB Right on target.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: And the boat? You’re not working too hard on it? McCALEB I’m keeping it afloat. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Good. I’11 see you ina bit. I want to check the blood work and get the tissue over to the lab. As Dr. Fox heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orderly wheels McCaleb’s gurney down the hall. As they pass one room, McCaleb looks over. A young boy is on the bed, his body tied by tubes to a heart lung machine. A man in a suit, his father, sits at the foot of the bed. As his eyes drift out into the hall at McCaleb... McCaleb looks away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: McCaleb reads it in his hospital room. He looks up as Dr. Fox comes through the door, holding a lab report.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Don’t start running laps yet, but I’m very pleased. No rejection, all the levels look good. I might lower your Prednisone in another week. McCALEB Good. I’m tired of shaving three times a day. Dr. Fox smiles, warms a stethoscope with her breath.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Lean forward please. He leans forward. She pulls down his johnny, listens to his heart through his back. McCALEB Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Don’t talk. (a beat) Sit up. She listens through his chest. For the first time we see it, the thirteen-inch white scar running over his heart like a rope. McCaleb half-grimaces at nothing in particular. Finally, she’s done.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Good. What did you want to ask me? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB That boy in room 604. What’s his blood type? Dr. Fox studies him a beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: It’s different than yours if that’s what you want to know. McCALEB How long has he been waiting?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: About half as long as you did. McCALEB What are his chances?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Maybe fifty-fifty. Maybe less. What’s bothering you, Terry? McCALEB (after a beat) When I was with the bureau we had to qualify on the range every year. You know, shoot targets. Circle around the heart scores more than the head. It’s called the ten ring. Highest score. Dr. Fox smiles sympathetically. Familiar ground to her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Typical. You hang around almost two years waiting for a heart, draw your string out and nearly don’t make it and now you wonder if we should’ve given it to you. You know what that is? McCALEB Bullshit?

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Exactly. Go home and enjoy your boat. I’11 see you next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb walks across the main dock. He passes a forty-two-foot Hunter sailboat called the Double-Down. BUDDY NOONE plays harmonica in the cockpit. He wears a bathrobe, his hair standing up on one side. An aging surfer, low maintenance live aboard.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Morning, Terry. McCALEB It’s two in the afternoon, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Whatever. Hey, heads up, man. McCALEB What?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (gesturing) Somebody’s on your boat. Two boats down. The Following Sea. A woman stands by the sliding door leading to the boat’s salon. McCaleb frowns.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Been here ten minutes. Looked harmless, I didn’t say anything. McCALEB (starts forward) Thanks, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOLLOWING SEA 17
dialogues.text: The woman -- GRACIELLA RIVERS -- stares out across the water. She doesn’t see McCaleb till he’s stepping down aboard. McCALEB Can I help you? She turns, a little startled.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: I’m looking for Terrel McCaleb. McCALEB You found him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: I read about you in the paper, Mr. McCaleb. ‘The Where Are They Now?’ column. You know, in the Metro section? McCALEB Look, before you start your story, I have to tell you, you’re not the first person to come out here and find me. (off no answer; she looks sad) I can recommend a good, private investigator. Someone who’1ll work hard and won’t rip you off.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: The article said you were good. It said you hated it whenever somebody got away. McCALEB If you read the article, then you also know what happened to me. I’m retired, Miss Rivers.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Graciella. I think you could help me. Maybe help yourself, too. McCALEB I don’t need the money.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: I’m not talking about money. Something weird about how she said it. Graciella reaches into her purse, hands McCaleb a photo: a smiling woman watching a boy blow out seven candles on a birthday cake. The woman looks quite a bit like Graciella. He looks at it, looks back at her. McCALEB Your sister?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Yes. And her son. McCALEB Which one? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Excuse me? McCALEB Which one is dead?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: My sister. Gloria Torres. Glory. Her son’s name is Raymond. McCaleb holds the photo out, sighs. McCALEB Look, Miss Rivers, I just can’t do this. I’m sorry. She makes no move to take the photo.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Look at it again. Please. Just one more time and then I’1l leave you alone. Tell me if you feel anything? McCALEB (irritated) I was an F.B.I. agent, not a psychic. Now do you want this photo back or not?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: I have a double. You know, two for the price of one. You’1l want to keep that one. McCALEB Why would I want to do that? Graciella reaches out her hand. Past the photo McCaleb still holds out. She places the palm of her hand on his chest, runs it slowly down the front of his shirt, her fingers tracing the scar beneath.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Your heart. It was my sister’s. (a beat) My phone number’s on the back if you change your mind. With that, Graciella steps up to the dock and starts away. Speechless, McCaleb watches her go, then turns over the photo. A number is scrawled on back.

dialogues.speaker: GLASS THERMOMETER 18
dialogues.text: The mercury rises, stops at 98.6 degrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb takes the thermometer out of his mouth, reads it. He picks up a clipboard with a temperature chart. Ina column he adds another in a series of dashes. No change. Looking at the mirror, he studies his eyes, then pulls off his shirt. Time to look at the scar. It’s a ritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb sits at the desk, turns on a light. Hanging from the light, a Lucite block which holds his FBI badge. Tacked on the corkboard beyond that, a laminated newspaper line-up of code killer victims. Under them: 903 472 568. McCaleb frowns at it and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb lies in his bunk staring up at the ceiling. Unable to sleep. Finally, he retrieves his watch from a slot on the wall. The glow-in-the-dark hands read 3:29 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full moon shines down on the all but deserted sight. McCaleb dials the number on the back of the photo. McCALEB Miss Rivers, it’s Terry McCaleb. I know it’s late, but -- (a beat) I’m going to go see the police tomorrow and ask about this. (another beat) Don’t thank me. I don’t want you to get your hopes up. I’m just going to take a look. I owe your sister that much. Now... He takes a note pad and pencil from his pocket. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB Before I start, I’1l need some information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up out front and McCaleb gets out, a box of doughnuts in hand. As he heads for the entrance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb steps to a counter. A YOUNG DETECTIVE steps over.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Can I help you? McCALEB Are Detectives Arrango or Walters in homicide?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Your name? McCALEB McCaleb. Tell them it’s about the Gloria Torres case. The young detective punches three digits into a phone, whispers something as he looks McCaleb over. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Down the hall. First door on your right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb has only gone a few steps when a solidly built man in a white shirt and tie steps in front of him. Gun in a shoulder harness. Detective Arrango from a few years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Mr. McCaleb. McCALEB Detective Arrango. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCaleb makes a point of shaking his hand.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: I thought you had died, or at least retired. My guy up front said you’re here about Glory Torres. McCALEB That’s right. Is there a place where we can talk?

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Talk about what? McCALEB I’m looking into her death.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Oh shit, here we go. Irritated, Arrango turns, snaps his fingers to get the attention of his partner Walters who’s on the phone. As Walters motions he’1ll be a minute...

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: You got five minutes before I toss you outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrango leads the way in, closes the door behind McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Have a seat. My partner will be here in a minute. McCALEB (sitting down) Want a doughnut?

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: (also sitting) Keep your doughnuts. It’s the sister, isn’t it? You’re working for the goddamn sister. Let me see your ticket. McCALEB I don’t have a license, if that’s what you mean. Arrango glares at him a beat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Jesus, it’s stuffy in here. Arrango gets up, adjusts a thermostat on the wall and goes back for his seat. As he does, McCaleb glances up at an air duct grill over the door.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: You say you’re conducting an investigation into the Gloria Torres homicide, is that correct? McCALEB (sighs) Yes, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: And you have no license in the state of California to operate as a private investigator, true? McCALEB True. Walters enters. Without looking, Arrango signals him not to interrupt. Walters leans against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Do you understand, Mr. McCaleb, that it is a crime in this state to operate as a private investigator without a license? McCALEB Can we skip the bullshit and turn off the tape and camera and just talk a minute? Besides, Walters is leaning against the microphone. You’re not picking anything up. Arrango turns as Walters jumps away from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Shuddup! McCALEB Have a doughnut, guys. I’m here to help.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: How do you know Graciella Rivers? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB She’s an acquaintance. She asked me to look into this. McCaleb opens the box of doughnuts. Walters looks to Arrango, whose face is stone. McCALEB Well, I’m going to have one. McCaleb takes out a cinnamon. After a beat, Walters grabs a glazed. Finally, against his better judgment, Arrango takes a powdered. They each chew a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: I don’t know what the sister told you, Mr. Former-F.B.I.-profiler, but this isn’t Charlie Manson or Ted fucking Bundy. It’s a convenience store robbery. Some mope with a mask and a gun and the right ratio of balls to brains. That’s all. McCALEB I know, but I told her I’d check it out. It’s been two months. I thought maybe you guys wouldn’t mind a fresh set of eyes. Walters looks at Arrango, shrugs a why not. McCALEB I’m not here to show you up. Anything I come up with, you’1l be the first to know.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: What do you want? McCALEB Copy me the murder book and the video walk-through on the crime scene. I was always good with crime scenes. Walters and Arrango exchange another look. Then...

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: I don’t think so, man. McCALEB Let me ask you something, does the sister call you much? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: All the time. Week in and week out I tell her the same thing. No suspects, no leads. McCALEB This could get her off your case. If I see what you got and say you boys did your best, she might back off. Arrango smiles at the thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: You say you were good with crime scenes? McCALEB Yeah, if you made a tape... Arrango winks at Walters, then looks back at McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: We got better than a crime scene tape. We got the crime. (stands) Come on. Bring those doughnuts with you. INT. LIEUTENANT’S OFFICE - TELEVISION SCREEN - DAY 27 The screen flickers on. A black and white surveillance camera view of the counter of a convenience store. A date and time line runs across the bottom of the screen. The frame is empty a few seconds until the counterman leans in over the register. He breaks open a roll of quarters.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: That’s Kyungwon Kang, the owner.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: He’s spending his last few seconds on the planet here. As he closes the register, a woman steps up. Easily recognizable from the photo -- Gloria Torres. Glory. She smiles as she sets a Hershey bar down on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Came in to buy a fucking candy bar. You believe that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB (softly) For her son... As Gloria hands a dollar bill over, a man in a black ski mask and black jumpsuit moves up behind Gloria. She’s still smiling as ski mask puts his right hand on her right shoulder and in one continuous move brings the muzzle of a handgun up to her left temple. Without hesitation, he pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Badda-bing! McCaleb grimaces as bloody mist jettisons from the wound. Ski mask holds her up as a shield, then raises his left hand to FIRE a ROUND into Mr. Kang. Kang vainly grapples for a hold on the counter like a man going over a cliff. Ski mask lowers Gloria’s body to the floor. Her head drops out of sight. Ski mask steps up as Mr. Kang pulls a revolver from under some papers bags. Ski mask shoots him in the face. Ski mask scoops the cash from the register, then picks up something off Mr. Kang’s arm. He then reaches for something on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: He picked up all the shells. Ski mask looks directly at the camera and says something. McCALEB No sound on the camera, right?

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: Right. Whatever he said there, he said to himself. Ski mask then makes one last pass on his way out.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: You ain’t gonna see that on ‘America’s Favorite Home Videos.’ McCALEB (ignoring comment) Can I see it again? Slowed down? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: It’s not over yet. McCALEB What?

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: The good Samaritan comes in now. On screen, a dark-haired, dark-complected man in jeans and a T-shirt enters. He hesitates, looks down at Gloria, then over the counter at Mr. Kang. He kneels over Gloria’s body. Almost immediately, he’s up and away.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: He went down the aisles looking for bandages. He actually wrapped her head with tape and paper towels. The good Samaritan is back doing just that.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Camera never got a good look at him. After he finished, he went outside, called 9-1-1 and split.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: Voice on the tape was Latino. We figure the guy was illegal. Afraid to stick around. McCALEB Too bad. He was there so soon, he probably saw the shooter’s car, maybe the shooter.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: We put out flyers, went on Channel 34. Nothing. McCALEB (re: TV) May I? Arrango shrugs, annoyed. McCaleb rewinds, starts the tape again. This time in slow motion. As the gun gets pressed up against Gloria Torres’ head, he freezes it. The smile has only half- left her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Arrango smirks as McCaleb scribbles the time: 22:41:39. McCaleb hesitates before resuming play.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Pause button’s not gonna help her now. McCaleb hits it. Gloria dies. The tape plays through ski mask saying something into the camera. McCALEB He winked.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: What? McCaleb rewinds, plays it slower. As ski mask says his line, he definitely winks. McCaleb freezes it again as the good Samaritan walks in. He notes the new time line: 22:42:55. As the tape finishes, McCaleb is visibly affected.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. F.B.I. man, tell us something we don’t know. McCaleb stares over at Arrango, hardens up. McCALEB The shooter’s been in the store before. He knew where the camera was. So he’s either from the neighborhood or he cased the place. Plus this wasn’t the first time. No hesitation, no panic, he picks up the brass. This guy’s done it before. Arrango and Walters exchange a look. Walters starts to say something, but Arrango holds up a hand to silence him. McCALEB What? Neither man answers. McCALEB How many others? Neither man answers again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB Can I see the murder book?

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Let us talk to the lieutenant and we’ll get back to you. Arrango and Walters both stand. Meeting over. McCALEB When?

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Give me a number. We’1l be in touch. That’s all he’s getting. Taking out a pen, McCaleb writes a number on the top of the doughnut box. He shoves it in Arrango’s hands, gives Walters a nasty look, then starts out with Arrango calling after him.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Hey, we don’t need your shit, McCaleb, we got a whole plateful of our own!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up and as McCaleb gets out... McCALEB Wait here. McCaleb studies the storefront a beat. There’s a pay phone right out front. A deep breath and he starts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb enters, smiling over at the elderly ASIAN WOMAN behind the counter. The counter where Mr. Kang died. She doesn’t smile back. McCaleb goes to the display racks full of candy and picks out a Hershey bar. He steps to the counter, sets it down. As the Asian Woman RINGS it up, McCaleb looks up at the surveillance camera. He then hands the woman a dollar. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB Are you Mrs. Kang?

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes. I know you? McCALEB No, it’s just... I heard what happened here. To your husband. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ASIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. (a beat) The only way to keep evil out is to not unlock door. We can’t do that. We must have business. McCaleb nods that he understands. As she hands him his change, he looks one more time at the surveillance camera, then once behind him. Playing the crime over in his head. As he exits, he nods to Mrs. Kang. McCALEB Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb steps to the pay phone. This is where the Good Samaritan stood. McCaleb reaches out, pretends to dial 9-1-1. A beat, then he scans the street. McCALEB’S POV - STREET 31 A wide, busy four-lane boulevard. Across the street -- a strip mall parking lot. A man sitting in a car. He lifts a newspaper almost the instant McCaleb notices him. McCALEB 32 Not alarmed. In fact, he’s about to dismiss it, when...

dialogues.speaker: CABBIE
dialogues.text: Hey! You gonna pay me or should I drive you somewhere else? McCaleb strides over to the cab, gets in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB The nearest public library. The Cabbie thinks a beat, then starts to pull away. McCaleb looks across the street. The car is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb is in the research section. On screen, he calls up the L.A. Times, accesses the search function. When it asks for key words, McCaleb types: "robbery, ski mask, shooting." He hits enter and waits. As the computer works, McCaleb dumps a handful of pills into the palm of his hand. As he chases them down with a bottle of water, the computer flashes a new screen. Two matches to the key words. McCaleb hits "print."

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. SHERIFF’S DEPARTMENT (WHITTIER) - DAY 34 The cab pulls up again. INT. DETECTIVE WINSTON’S OFFICE (HOMICIDE) - DAY 35 The door opens. A DEPUTY shows McCaleb in.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Detective Winston said to wait here. She’1ll be right with you. The Deputy leaves McCaleb alone. McCaleb steps over to a wall of citations and a smattering of press clippings. One is from a police magazine: It shows both McCaleb and Det. Jaye Winston receiving citations for an arrest of "The Cemetery Man." The door opens and JAYE enters, looks happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: How’s it going, Terry? I heard you got a new ticker. (CONTINUED)
35 McCALEB (as they shake hands) Yeah, and I’m doing okay. You?

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Same old same old. What’s up? You on a private ticket now? McCALEB No, just doing a favor for a friend.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: What case is it? McCaleb pulls the LA Times library printouts from his bag. McCALEB James Cordell. A.T.M. holdup on January twenty-two. Newspaper says he was shot by a guy wearing a ski mask.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Who’s the friend you’re doing the favor for? McCALEB Graciella Rivers. Her sister was shot in a convenience store holdup two weeks ago. Guy with a ski mask. An odd beat. McCALEB So did I get it right? Are they connected?

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Same guy, Terry. Out of your orbit, though. Just a scumbag with a gun. Three-strike shit, that’s all. McCALEB What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: You know, guys with two felony convictions. A third puts them away for life. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JAYE (CONT’D) So instead of leaving witnesses, they kill ‘em. Robbery, murder, it’s the same sentence either way. McCALEB I saw the boys in L.A. They showed me the tape, but wouldn’t copy me the book. I bet they copied you. (a beat) You owe me one, Jaye.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Don’t you think I know that?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK AND WHITE VIDEO IMAGE 36
dialogues.text: James Cordell, 35, as seen by an ATM camera. He slides his card into the cash machine. He hesitates, looks back over his right shoulder, tracking something behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shooter’s back there, but I’m betting the mask isn’t on yet. Otherwise Cordell would’ve run. Cordell turns back to the machine, waits. Suddenly, the gun comes into frame, just kissing Cordell’s left temple. Jaye freeze-frames.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Heckler and Koch nine milli. Same model as the Valley tape. She hits play and James Cordell’s brains are blown out. He falls away to reveal the same shooter. Ski mask and black jumpsuit aside, it’s him. As he reaches for the cash in the slot, he mouths something. McCaleb freezes it. McCALEB He said something in the Valley tape, also.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Guy’s a chatterbox. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB Have you brought in a lip reader? Jaye looks at him for a beat, feels foolish that she hasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: I’11 get on it. McCALEB He took the money from the machine not the victim.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: So? McCALEB He took it from the bank. Makes it a federal offense. Jaye shrugs, hits play. Ski mask picks up the shell casing and goes. Jaye fast forwards. After a minute, she hits play. A man, James Lockridge, steps up, crouches by Cordell’s body. Lockridge is stocky, bald across the top.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: James Lockridge. He pulled into the bank parking lot. Almost got sideswiped by a sedan roaring out. Said it was a white guy, but couldn’t give us anything else. He called for an ambulance. Cordell died on the way to the hospital. McCALEB You got any leads at all?

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Been following the three-strikes thing. Looking up local stick-up men with two or more falls under their belts. I think the man in the ski mask is one of them. Used to be a robber, now he’s a robbing murderer. McCALEB What about the gun? Heckler and Koch. Expensive for a holdup man and weird that he’d hang onto it after the first killing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: I figured he stole it, but that didn’t lead anywhere. I hate to say it, McCaleb, but I think we’re going to need fresh blood to solve this one. McCALEB Can you copy the murder books, Jaye? Yours and L.A.’s?

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: I’1l ask the captain, but I don’t see why not. He was the lieutenant on the Cemetery Man case. McCALEB Glad someone got promoted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAMES LOCKERIDGE sits at his cubicle typing into a 26. 37 38 computer. A bit of a nerd, he looks up as the office Manager leads McCaleb over. McCALEB (extending hand) Mr. Lockeridge, I’m Terry McCaleb. Thanks for seeing me. Lockridge looks from the hand to McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKRIDGE
dialogues.text: Are you a policeman? McCALEB F.B.I. Retired. I’m investigating a related case for another victim’s family.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKRIDGE
dialogues.text: Good. Police are stupid. McCALEB Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: LOCKRIDGE
dialogues.text: Didn’t they tell you? McCaleb looks at him, shrugs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOCKRIDGE
dialogues.text: Why would they? When I found the guy shot, I called 9-1-1. They got the address transposed and they sent the ambulance to the wrong place. It took twenty minutes. Guy was breathing the whole time. He might’ve made it if they hadn’t fucked up. McCALEB These things happen, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKRIDGE
dialogues.text: No. They fucked up and the guy died. I’m real busy. I agreed to see you because you were already here. What do you want? McCALEB I read your statement, but I’d like to hear from you what happened.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKRIDGE
dialogues.text: I needed cash. As I pulled into the lot, a guy driving out almost hit me. It was dark. All I saw was it was a car. No plates, no face, nothing. I walk up to the A.T.M. and there’s a guy bleeding. He must’ve got it right before I got there. I call 9-1-1 and ten minutes later, they went driving past us. Past us. McCALEB Did you notice anything at all, detail-wise?

dialogues.speaker: LOCKRIDGE
dialogues.text: Yeah. That it could’ve been me. It could’ve been him finding me. With that ambulance driving right on by!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lonely spot even during the day. McCaleb steps up. He stands there a beat, looks down at the ground where the bloodstain still isn’t quite gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCaleb inserts his ATM card, looks back over his shoulder, then up and down the street. He closes his eyes, replaying the crime in his mind. Suddenly, a hand reaches up toward McCaleb’s shoulder! Someone’s behind him. As the hand comes down... McCaleb wheels to face a longhaired MAN wearing Wayfarer sunglasses and a single, dangling crucifix earring.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You done? McCaleb blinks in surprise, then gathers his wits. Grunting that he is, he takes his ATM card from the slot and walks away. The man watches after him a beat, then turns to the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi pulls up and lets McCaleb out. He carries a stack of files and videotapes. He looks tired. Buddy raises a beer from the deck of the Double Down.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Here’s to you, Terry. McCaleb nods, continues past, then turns, looks at Buddy. McCALEB What do you got going tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Same as always. A big fat goose egg. McCALEB I need a driver for a few days. Ten bucks an hour plus meals.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (perking up) What is it, an investigation? McCALEB I’m looking for a driver, Buddy, not a partner.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m in. Whose car. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB We take yours, I pay for gas. We take mine, I sit in the back. It’s got air bags up front.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Right, cuz of your chest, right? McCaleb nods, no patience left for the day.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Let’s take mine. I’d feel like too much of a chauffeur with you in the back. McCALEB (heads off) See you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You look tired, McCaleb. You should get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The evidence is laid out. Both cases, crime-scene photos, etc... McCaleb rubs his eyes, makes a note on a legal pad. He then opens a Thomas Guide, begins tracking streets.

dialogues.speaker: GLASS THERMOMETER 42
dialogues.text: The mercury rises, stops at 99.8 degrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb takes the thermometer out of his mouth, reads it. It takes a moment for it to register. Finally, he picks up the clipboard with the temperature chart. In a column where there have only ever been dashes, he jots 99.8 degrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re suddenly in a BLACK AND WHITE world. MR. KANG looks up from the register and smiles in an unfriendly way. McCaleb stands across form him.

dialogues.speaker: MR. KANG
dialogues.text: You don’t deserve it. McCALEB What? Suddenly, there’s a hand on McCaleb’s shoulder, the barrel of a revolver on his temple. McCaleb turns to find the man in the SKI MASK. He lowers the GUN to McCaleb’s chest -- the heart.

dialogues.speaker: SKI MASK
dialogues.text: Ten ring. BOOM! SHOT through the heart, McCaleb starts an impossibly slow descent to the floor. As he falls he looks back toward Ski Mask. The eyes watch him go. They look remarkably like his own eyes... Then comes the wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having landed in his own bunk, McCaleb wakes in a cold sweat. It takes him a moment to realize where he is.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CEDAR’S-SINAI - EXAMINATION ROOM - DAY (NEXT 46

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: DR. BONNIE FOX sits across from McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Murdered? What are you talking about? McCALEB She was shot in the head in a robbery, then lived long enough for me to get her heart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: You’re not supposed to know anything about your donor. How do you know this? McCALEB Her sister tracked me down. She read a piece about me in the paper, about the fact that I hada rare blood type, the same as her sister’s. My surgery was the same day her sister died.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: What does she want? Money? McCaleb actually laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: I’m glad you can find it funny. McCALEB Don’t you see? She wants me to find out who did it. She wants me to solve her sister’s murder.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Give me this woman’s name. Right now. McCaleb just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: You’re not thinking of doing this. McCALEB I started yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: (furious) And today you’re running a fever! You are sixty days post transplant! As your doctor I’m ordering you not to do this. He doesn’t answer; she softens.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: You have to respect the gift you were given, Terry. McCALEB I do and I am. It was her gift. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCALEB It’s supposed to be an accident. 99 out of 100 donors, an accident leading to a fatal head injury. This is different.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: How? How is it different? A heart is a heart. McCALEB (standing) An accident is fate. A murder is evil.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Oh please -- McCALEB This gift that you talk about, the only reason I have it is because of this evil, hateful thing that someone did.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: You’re not making a lot of sense. McCALEB She went into that store to get a candy bar for her kid and ends up -- I can’t explain -- Dr. Fox reaches out, takes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: You know the little boy in room 604? He’s waiting on a heart that isn’t coming. That could be you, Terry. This is your one chance. Tell this woman no. Save yourself and tell her no. McCALEB I can’t... Dr. Fox slowly pulls her hands back.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: You are gambling with your life. If you start getting infection or rejection, we’re not going to be able to save you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB I don’t have a choice.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Neither do I. I can no longer be your doctor, Terry. I can’t be around while you do this. McCALEB Look, Doc --

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: I’1l have your records ready this afternoon. Good luck, Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a waitress uniform, Graciella steps over to the phone. The MANAGER doesn’t look too happy as he hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Make it quick.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Hello? McCALEB (V.O.) Graciella? It’s McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb stands in the booth, his head pressed up against the glass. Buddy stands a short distance away, looking concerned for his friend.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Did something happen? McCALEB Tell me about her. INTERCUT the following:

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB Glory. Tell me something about her. The better feel I have for her, the better I’1l be at this. She thinks a beat, knows this is important to him.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Is there a kitchen on that boat of yours? McCALEB Yeah, a galley.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Is it big enough to cook a real meal? McCALEB Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: You want to know my sister? Then you have to meet her son. Everything that was good about her is in him. I/’11 bring him by tonight and make you dinner. McCALEB I’d like that... So you know, most cases turn on some detail that was missed or didn’t seem important. It can be the key. That’s what I have to find.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: You have Glory’s heart. She’11 guide you. McCaleb hangs up; the words weigh heavy. He steps out.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You okay, Terry? Where to?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 49 INT. BUDDY’S CAR - DAY 49 They pull into the lot of a West Valley industrial park.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What are we doing here? (CONTINUED)

49 McCALEB Sheriff’s department checked out a list of three strike robbery suspects. Also, a list of locations where HK P7 pistols were stolen in the past few years. Last night I charted the site of each theft along with the home and job location of each man on the list.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I get it. Like a cross reference. You want to see if they overlap, right? McCALEB One name sticks out like a whore in church. Mikail Bolotov. Two time loser. Lives a mile from the market where Gloria Torres died. Works four blocks from a Canoga Park home where a Heckler and Koch was stolen in December. Buddy lets out a low whistle.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: So why haven’t they arrested this guy? Bolo... Bolo... McCALEB Bolotov.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Russian sonuvabitch! McCALEB They don’t know about the gun. Plus he’s got an alibi. Time card. He punched out at work after the Cordell murder.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: A friend could’ve done that. McCaleb nods, looks up at the building.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: But I still don’t know what we’re doing here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB He works inside. I’m going to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Cool. As McCaleb starts out, Buddy follows. McCALEB Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: We’1l lean on him. Good cop, bad cop. McCALEB You’re staying in the car, Buddy. Buddy mutters disappointment, but his eyes widen as McCaleb fishes a gun in a canvas holster from his leather bag. As he clips it to his belt...

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Hey, what are you expecting in there? McCALEB Nothing. It’s more of a prop than anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheap, industrial look clocks are manufactured here. A RECEPTIONIST looks up at McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Can I help you? McCaleb puts his hands on his hips, carefully lets his jacket open to expose his gun. The Receptionist spots it. McCALEB I’m conducting a follow-up on a sheriff’s department inquiry of February Third.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Just a moment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She picks up a phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Toliver, it’s Wendy. There’s a man from the sheriff's department here about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Built into the wall above and with a window looking out onto the manufacturing floor. McCaleb stands across from a harried MR. TOLIVER.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TOLIVER
dialogues.text: We’re awfully busy, Mr. McCaleb. McCALEB I’1l get to the point then. A few months ago you spoke to two sheriff's detectives about an employee named Bolotov.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TOLIVER
dialogues.text: Yes? McCALEB I’m investigating that case now. I need to ask some additional questions.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TOLIVER
dialogues.text: I’11 tell you what I told the others. Michael Bolotov was working that day. You can see his time card if you’d like. McCALEB How many employees do you have on the floor at any given time?

dialogues.speaker: MR. TOLIVER
dialogues.text: Eight-five. McCALEB Any chance one of them could’ve punched Bolotov out?

dialogues.speaker: MR. TOLIVER
dialogues.text: (shrugs) We’ve been in business sixteen years. It’s happened. McCaleb looks out onto the floor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB Is Bolotov working today? Mr. Toliver steps up, points down on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TOLIVER
dialogues.text: That’s him there. McCaleb is looking at a man in a black T-shirt with sleeves stretched tight over powerful, tattoo-laced arms. BOLOTOV. McCALEB Bolotov... Is he Russian?

dialogues.speaker: MR. TOLIVER
dialogues.text: Yeah. They’re good workers and they don’t complain. They don’t mind being paid shit, either. McCALEB I’d like to speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: MR. TOLIVER
dialogues.text: In here? McCALEB I’m sure you want to continue to cooperate, don’t you? After a big sigh from Mr Toliver...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE WITH Bolotov as he climbs up. He moves with a jailhouse strut as he enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb waits, alone. McCALEB Sit down. Bolotov moves to a chair, sits without hesitation. McCALEB The night of January seventeen. Tell me about it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: I told them before. I work that night. McCALEB So you said. But things are different now. We know things we didn’t know then.

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: What things? McCALEB Burglary at that house on Mason. Two blocks from here, remember? That where you got the gun, wasn’t it, Bolotov?

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (biceps bulging) What gun? McCALEB How about February Seventh? You got an alibi for that night, too?

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: I don’t know that night. McCALEB Sure you do. That’s the night you walked into the Sherman Market and killed two people. Bolotov’s eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Who are you? You’re not a cop. McCaleb just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: (standing) Cops are in twos. Who are you? McCALEB I’m the one who’s going to take you down. You did it, Bolotov, and I’m going to prove it. Without warning, Bolotov rushes forward. As McCaleb Bolotov slams into his chest, sending McCaleb sprawling over the back of the chair. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pinning McCaleb’s neck with a knee, he goes through his pockets. Tossing the gun away, he checks McCaleb’s wallet.

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: No badge. See, no cop. Bolotov checks the driver’s license.

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Terr-ell Mack-kay-leeb. He digs his knee in a bit harder.

dialogues.speaker: BOLOTOV
dialogues.text: Maybe I pay you a visit one day, yes? Standing, Bolotov grabs the chair, raises it over his head. At that moment, the door opens and Mr. Toliver steps in. Bolotov hurls the chair through the glass, then leaps with ease to the manufacturing floor below. McCaleb tries to stand, then collapses to the floor clutching at his chest. McCALEB Shit...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DETECTIVE WINSTON’S OFFICE - HOMICIDE - DAY 54 Looking ragged, McCaleb sits across from Jaye Winston. She’s angry. McCALEB Think for a minute, Jaye. Bolotov’s alibi is about as solid as a loaf of bread.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: You think, Terry. You’ve got no badge. And even if you did, it would be the wrong one. McCALEB The hell with that. Bolotov. I like him for this, Jaye. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Guy’s a convict. He could’ve done what he did for a hundred reasons. McCALEB You should put out a pick-up on him.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: (stepping over) You look like crap, Terry. Jaye puts her palm on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: You got a fever. Go home. McCALEB Bolotov.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: I had a car go by his apartment, but he’s already gone. Split. McCALEB I hit a nerve.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: I’1l say. You remember my lieutenant who became a captain? McCaleb nods.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: He’s not too happy. He doesn’t want to hear from you or about you again. We’1ll send a sheriff by your boat at five to pick up the files and tapes. Understood? McCaleb sighs, nods again. Jaye looks away.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Will that give you enough time to make copies of everything? McCaleb looks back over, smiles. McCALEB I already did. It’s her turn to smile. But as McCaleb stands to go... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: By the way. Lip reader came in. He’s ninety percent sure that the shooter was saying ‘Happy Valentine’s Day.’ McCALEB That sounds hinky, Jaye. Not like your average mutt.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) What’s average these days?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Bluntly: the gun comes up and blows her brains out. Mr. Kang is shot next. The shooter picks up the shells and mouths to the camera with McCaleb speaking in perfect synch with him. McCALEB (V.O.) Happy Valentine’s Day. The image freezes, rewinds, and plays again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb sits by the TV assaulting himself with the same image over and over. The moment is broken by the sound and motion of FOOTSTEPS touching down on the deck overhead. McCaleb hits freeze, sparing Gloria death by a fraction of a second. He stands, heads through the door to the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb steps out to find Graciella and a ten-year-old boy RAYMOND stepping on. Graciella carries a bag of groceries. She reads McCaleb’s surprise.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: (smiling) You forgot, didn’t you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB (embarrassed) No -- I mean, sort of, for the last few hours. I got lost...

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: It’s okay. We can do it another time. McCALEB Are you kidding? We’re going to have dinner. Is this Raymond?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: (nodding) Raymond, this is Mr. McCaleb. The man I was telling you about. This is his boat. McCaleb steps over, shakes Raymond’s little hand. The boy looks about curiously.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: What’s the Following Sea? McCALEB That’s the one you have to watch out for. The one that’s right behind you.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: (re: groceries) Where’s the galley? McCALEB (pointing) Through there. Graciella walks past them, down into the salon.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Can you fish off this boat? McCALEB Sure. Why don’t I get you a pole and -- McCaleb stops short, looks back over his shoulder. McCALEB Wait here, Raymond. As McCaleb starts down into the salon.  58 59 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graciella stands in shock before the TV staring at the frozen image of her sister, the barrel of the revolver about to touch the side of her head. Unable to look away, her trembling finger reaches for the play button. Just before she hits it, McCaleb is there. He switches the screen off. McCALEB I’m sorry. You shouldn’t have seen that.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Was she, was she ever scared? McCALEB No. She never knew at all. Graciella looks at the files, videotapes and notes on the chart table. Then she looks at the TV and back to McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: What I’ve asked you to do -- It isn’t fair, is it? McCALEB (after a beat) There’s a restaurant over the marine store. Good food and a great view of the sunset. Why don’t we have dinner there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After dinner. McCaleb and Graciella walk. Raymond runs ahead of them chasing sea gulls, chucking an occasional rock into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Why do you live on a boat? McCALEB I hate to mow the grass. She laughs. McCaleb smiles at the sight, looks to Raymond. McCALEB Is he going to stay with you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: (nods) I’m the only one. His father isn’t around. McCALEB Your sister was a good person. I can tell that by Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Thank you... How’s it going, McCaleb? Any hope? McCaleb looks her over, judging her strength. Then: McCALEB I want you to start thinking about your sister.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? McCALEB Make a list for me of places she would go, friends she would see, any routines she had.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: All right. How come? McCALEB Just an angle I’m working on. Did she ever mention a James Cordell to you?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: No. McCALEB You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Positive. Why? McCALEB It’s too premature to get into right now.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: (stops) You think this James Cordell killed her? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCALEB

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Then what? McCALEB Cordell was killed during an A.T.M. hold-up six weeks before Gloria. It looks like the same gunman.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: So why would Gloria know him? They were both just in the wrong place at the wrong time, right? McCALEB It’s a hunch, but this investigation was run under the theory that the locations were chosen and the victims were random. I think it might be the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: What? McCALEB To check it out I need to see if your sister and Cordell had anything in common. Some intersection that hooks them to each other or to the gunman.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: I’m not following you. McCALEB In the bureau we had what we call a full field investigation. That’s all I’m doing. Ahead, Raymond turns and looks back:

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Come on! McCaleb waves. They start forward. After some silence.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: There is one thing that’s always bothered me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCALEB What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: It’s nothing. McCALEB What?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Glory had a piece of jewelry. It was like her lucky charm. She always wore it. But when they gave me her personal things, it was missing. McCALEB What was it?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: A single earring. A dangling crucifix. McCaleb is gone. Lost in sudden, anxious thought. Graciella

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: What does it mean? takes McCaleb’s arm. McCaleb snaps back out. McCALEB Uh, certain killers take souvenirs.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: God, that’s creepy. (a beat) Are you okay? He focuses on her as he realizes the killer was at the ATM machine. McCALEB I just, I missed my medicine. I should get back to the boat and take it.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: We have to go, too. Raymond has homework. (to Raymond) Raymond! Come say thank you to Mr. McCaleb! (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GRACIELLA (CONT’D) (to McCaleb) You’re sure you’re okay. McCALEB Fine. But nothing’s fine right now. And as the sun sets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze Frame as Gloria Torres steps to the counter, head turned. McCaleb steps up to the screen, puts his finger on it. Grainy, but you can see: the crucifix earring. PLAY. Gloria is shot. Kang is shot. As the shooter lowers Gloria’s upper torso out of frame, McCaleb goes to jog mode. The shooter rises back into frame. McCaleb jogs back and forth over the shooter’s hand as it slides in and out of his pocket. He’s taken the earring!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb steps out to the deck of The Following Sea. McCALEB Hey, Buddy! A few beats before a bleary Buddy staggers up on deck.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What’s up, Terry? McCALEB You're working tomorrow. Six AM.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Cool. As Buddy turns, he kicks into part of the pile of personal stuff heaped everywhere. As it starts to spill over the side and sink to the bottom:

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Aww shit, Terry!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 62 63 49. INT. BUDDY’S CAR - DAY 62 Driving through the desert toward Lancaster.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Who wants to go to the desert anyhow? McCALEB You go where the clues lead.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Don’t any clues lead to the beach for crying out loud?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy waits in the car as McCaleb heads up the walk. He rings the bell. A few moments before MRS. CORDELL answers. She looks sad. McCALEB Mrs. Cordell?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: Yes. McCALEB I’m Terry McCaleb. I called you last night. (no answer) Is this a bad time?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: As opposed to a good time? McCALEB Poor choice of words. Can we talk?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: (pointing past) Is that your partner in the car? McCALEB Uh, my driver.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: Oh. I thought of hiring a private investigator, but I just couldn’t afford to. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks wall. 50. 63 at the two little bikes leaned against the

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: Couldn’t afford to find out who killed my husband. (looks up) Do you work for the police? McCALEB I’m a retired F.B.I. agent. A friend of the family of a woman who was killed in Canoga Park. We think it was the same gunman in both cases.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: I see. McCALEB First of all, I’m sorry. I know it doesn’t matter what a stranger thinks, but you have my sympathy. From what I read in the file, James was a good man.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: (smiles) It’s funny to hear him called James. Everyone called him Jimmy. And he was a very good man. How can I help, Mr. McCaleb? McCaleb takes out a photo and hands it to her. It’s the shot of Gloria Torres and Raymond that Graciella gave him. McCALEB Do you recognize this woman? Mrs. Cordell studies it. McCALEB Does she look like someone your husband could’ve known?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: No, I don’t think so. Was she the victim in Canoga Park? McCALEB Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hands 51.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: Is that her son? McCALEB Yes. That’s Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. How could my husband have known her? Are you suggesting they may have -- McCALEB No, Mrs. Cordell, nothing like that.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: Then like what? McCALEB Somewhere your husband and Miss Torres may have crossed the shooter’s path. The relationship is between the victims and the shooter. I need to know if your husband and Miss Torres had anything in common. It may seem like nothing. They both ate at the same restaurant for example.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: (figuring along) A restaurant the killer went to. McCALEB Yes, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: That sounds like stalking, not robbery. McCALEB To be honest, robbery may not have been the motive here. him back the photo. McCALEB Was anything missing when they turned over your husband’s personal effects? His wristwatch? Wedding ring?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB Would he have been in Canoga Park, the West Valley in the weeks before the shooting?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: No. As a matter of fact he’d just spent a month up in Northern California working on the aqueduct up there. He went into Los Angeles maybe twice a year. When my husband wasn’t working, Mr. McCaleb, he was home. With me. About the most exotic thing he did was give blood every few months or so. McCaleb nods, sorry for what he’s already put her through. A silent beat. He looks over toward the garage. There’s a Chevy Suburban, boxes piled behind it like no one ever drives it. McCALEB Was that your husband’s car?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: Yes. McCALEB Did he keep anything personal inside it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: A picture of the kids on the dashboard. McCALEB And that’s still there?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I would think, but someone from the sheriff's department drove it home. I haven’t been in it since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cordell opens the door to the Suburban. McCaleb looks over her shoulder. There on the dash, a photo of two little girls. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: There it is. McCaleb can’t quite hide his disappointment. Still... McCALEB Did he have a favorite knick- knack, a coffee mug, anything?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: No. I’m sorry. McCALEB That’s fine, Mrs. Cordell. What would help is in the next few days if you could write down any routines your husband had or --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. His sunglasses. McCALEB Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: They always hung from the rearview mirror. He kept them on a cord. They’re missing. McCALEB What kind of sunglasses were they?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: Wayfarers. He had them for years. As an image flashes in McCaleb’s mind:

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Wayfarer sunglasses and a dangling crucifix earring.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You done?

dialogues.speaker: CORDELL GARAGE 66
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cordell looks at McCaleb. He focuses on her as he realizes the killer was behind him at the ATM machine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. CORDELL
dialogues.text: I said, what do you think it means? McCaleb gets a hold of himself. McCALEB Probably nothing. Thanks for all your help, Mrs. Cordell. I/’11 call you as soon as I learn something. McCaleb starts away...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BUDDY’S CAR - DAY 67 Driving away. McCaleb takes a handful of pills, washes them down with a swig of bottled water.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Easy, Mac. What’s the matter? McCALEB I saw him, Buddy. I saw the killer. He was behind me at the bank. At the A.T.M. machine.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: That’s crazy. That’s the last place he’d be. McCALEB No, it fits into the profile.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What profile? Recovering, McCaleb clams up. McCALEB Let’s go. L.A. County Sheriff’s. In Whittier.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: But I still don’t get it. Why would -- (off McCaleb’s look) Never mind, I’m just the driver. McCALEB Now you got it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: If this lasts much longer, I want a raise.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 68 INT. SHERIFF’S OFFICE (WHITTIER) - FROM DESK - DAY 68 A DEPUTY looks across at McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Detective Winston’s out in the field. Can I take a message? McCALEB Just tell her McCaleb was here. As McCaleb turns to go...

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: Hey! She wanted to talk to you, Mr. McCaleb. As McCaleb turns back...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 69 INT. SHERIFF’S OFFICE (WHITTIER) - DISPATCH - DAY 69 The dispatcher hands McCaleb the radio mic. McCALEB This is McCaleb, Jaye. Jaye’s response is GARBLED until...

dialogues.speaker: JAYE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (over speaker) +... and I’m en route. You should get yourself down here. McCALEB I didn’t copy the first part of that.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I said, we got Bolotov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dirt way bisecting fenced in back yards. Police lines have been set up. Jaye greets McCaleb as he walks up with Buddy in tow. As she waves McCaleb through, he looks back at Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I know, I know. Wait here. McCALEB AND JAYE 721 Walk down the alley.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Trash collectors found him an hour ago. We’re guessing he’s been here since early this morning. Ahead: Arrango and Walters. McCaleb spots them. McCALEB What are they doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, this alley is the line. McCALEB What line?

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: South side is L.A.P.D. North side is the sheriff’s department. We’re not sure of the jurisdiction yet. Arrango turns to McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Looks like you shook him out of his tree, old man. Dumb bastard killed himself. He points to the ground between two trash bins. Bolotov sits there slumped, the side of his head blown open. Walters holds up an evidence bag: a 9mm pistol inside.

dialogues.speaker: WALTERS
dialogues.text: Heckler & Koch 9 millimeter. Same as both murders. Ballistics should confirm it. (CONTINUED)
721 McCALEB Wait a minute. What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Case closed. Sounds good, don’t it? McCALEB No. Bolotov doesn’t fit the profile.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: The profile of what? McCALEB A serial killer.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa! McCALEB These people were stalked and killed where the shooter knew there’d be a camera. Personal items, trophy items were taken.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you talking about? McCALEB I was at the A.T.M. crime scene yesterday. I didn’t realize it at the time, but the shooter was in line behind me. He was wearing James Cordell’s sunglasses and Gloria Torres’ earring. Walters and Arrango exchange a look. Arrango reaches into his pocket for two more evidence bags. One holds sunglasses, the other a crucifix earring.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Found the stuff in his left hand. I don’t care what we call him; we got him. McCALEB This guy had long hair.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Could it have been a wig? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB (rattled) I don’t know... Maybe. Jaye looks him over, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Maybe you should sit down, Terry.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Maybe pops should lay down.

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Arrango. There’s a commotion with FORENSICS over the body.

dialogues.speaker: FORENSICS
dialogues.text: Give me the tweezers. There’s something between his teeth. The detectives turn as the tweezers fish out:

dialogues.speaker: FORENSICS
dialogues.text: It’s a bullet. Indeed, a partially flattened slug.

dialogues.speaker: FORENSICS
dialogues.text: That looks like a .38 to me. As Forensics One nods in agreement...

dialogues.speaker: JAYE
dialogues.text: Why would he put a .38 slug in his mouth? McCALEB Same reason he died on the jurisdiction line. He didn’t do it. Someone’s jerking us off.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Well he did it in my book! McCaleb looks over. McCALEB You know what you are? You’re worried.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: (starting forward) That so? What am I worried about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB You’re worried I’m going to break the case. You don’t care about the people killed or hurt. You just don’t want me doing what you can’t. Arrango steps forward, gets in his face.

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: What the fuck is it to you? On the you, Arrango pokes McCaleb in the chest. McCaleb grabs Arrango’s hand, bends the thumb to a pressure point. McCALEB You know Gloria Torres? The victim you don’t give a shit about? I got her heart. I’m alive because she’s dead. As Arrango hunches in pain, McCaleb speaks into his ear. McCALEB That cuts me into this in a big way. So I don’t care about your feelings. You’re an asshole and that’s fine, but I’m not backing out till we get this guy. McCaleb lets go of Arrango, stiff-arms him back. McCALEB (intense) I don’t care if it’s you, me or somebody else, but I’m in this one for the whole ride. As McCaleb starts away...

dialogues.speaker: ARRANGO
dialogues.text: Stay out of my city, McCaleb! I come across you in the field and that’s going to be trouble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy walks with McCaleb. Buddy looks at his friend, sees he doesn’t look too good. As they reach the Double- Down, McCaleb pauses and fishes in his pocket. He comes out with about forty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB Shit... What do you figure I owe you, Buddy?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Um, about two hundred or so. McCALEB Sounds right.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: You look like shit, Terry. You should take a nap or something. McCaleb nods, but isn’t really listening. McCALEB You take a check?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Sure. McCALEB I’1l bring it over. McCaleb starts toward his boat, then looks back over his shoulder. McCALEB Should I make it out to Buddy?

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Jasper. Jasper Noone. McCALEB I knew the Noone part.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: I look more like a Buddy than a Jasper, huh? (calling after) Take a nap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb finishes writing out the check. He tears it out, pins it to the corkboard over his desk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A sign as McCaleb turns and looks at the evidence piled in two cardboard boxes. The task before him has grown daunting. As he wipes the sweat from his brow... A dip as someone outside steps down to the deck. McCaleb turns to the slider. Graciella is there with Raymond. She motions for Raymond to wait outside, then she enters. McCALEB Graciella.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Is it true? McCALEB What?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: On the radio. They said they found a Russian man who may be the killer. McCALEB I don’t know. I don’t think so, but I don’t know. She just stands there looking at him. Not knowing hurts.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: But they said... McCALEB Might be just a couple of cops looking for headlines. He looks at her, realizes. McCALEB I’m sorry, Graciella. I just don’t know. Graciella finally just nods. She holds up a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: I did what you asked. I made a list of all of Glory’s routines. McCALEB Good. Thank you. Graciella tries not to cry as she recites. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He rifles 62.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: She stopped at that market a lot. almost every night. She took Raymond to McDonald’s a lot. The one on Ventura in Reseda. She used to go bowling, but not for a while. She visited our aunt every Thursday. She’s in a nursing home in Culver City. She gave blood every couple of months and she dropped Raymond off at school every -- McCALEB Wait a minute. Did you say blood?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Yeah. She had that rare type. Same as you. McCALEB A.B. with the C.M.V. negative.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: The hospital would have paid her, but she wouldn’t take it. McCALEB That’s it... They both gave blood. It’s the blood.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? McCALEB Cordell and your sister. I talked to the widow. She said he gave blood every few months. through the Cordell files. He reads, then: McCALEB Shit. This is just a preliminary report. No toxicology and no blood. I’ve got to call his wife.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Terry, slow down. What are you talking about? McCALEB The link. It’s blood. Blood has to be the link. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graciella waits as McCaleb waits for someone to answer his call. Finally, he hangs up. McCALEB Mrs. Cordell isn’t home.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Is there another way to find out? McCALEB If he gave blood regularly, he’d be on the computer.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: What computer? McCALEB The BOPRA computer. When someone needs rare blood. They have one at Cedars.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: (intense) I’m coming with you. McCALEB What about Raymond? They look across to where Raymond talks to Buddy who sits on a lawn chair on the deck of the Double Down.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY 75
dialogues.text: Squinting over at McCaleb.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: What do you mean baby-sitting? McCALEB How much do you charge? Buddy looks over at Raymond and sighs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Beer. A case of beer an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCaleb and Graciella walk down. McCaleb looks in the door at the same little boy as before. He looks a little more frail. They continue around past the nurse’s station. Dr. Fox is there grabbing a patient file.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Terry? McCALEB Hey, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? Are you -- McCALEB I’m fine. Is there an empty room we can use for a few minutes? I need to talk to you. She notices Graciella for the first time, looks at McCaleb, then shakes her head in annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They file in. Dr. Fox closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: You have five minutes? Who is this? McCALEB This is Graciella Rivers. I told you about her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: You’re the one who started him on this. Look at him. His color, the lines under his eyes. A week ago he was fine! He was perfect, godamnit! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: McCALEB It was my choice. Everything. choice.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: (wheeling on him) Shut up! McCaleb blinks in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Sit down. McCaleb does as he’s told.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Open your mouth. She sticks a thermometer in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Take your shirt off. 65. 77 My He does as he’s told. Graciella’s eyes widen at the scar. Dr. Fox sticks a cold stethoscope on his back.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: (to Graciella) What do you two want? McCALEB We need to --

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Keep that thermometer in your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: My sister was murdered. So was another man. It was the same killer. McCaleb found a link between my sister and the other man. They both gave blood.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: My sister was the same type as McCaleb. AB with CMW negative. McCaleb says it’s 1 in 200. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dr. Fox takes out the thermometer, reads it.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Shit. (then, to McCaleb) What do you want? McCALEB Check the BOPRA computer. James Cordell. If he’s listed, I want to know what his blood type is.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: That’s unethical. McCALEB You have to help. If my hunch is right, the killer has access already.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: I don’t know... McCALEB If you can’t protect the integrity of the system you work in, then you have no system.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Okay. I’11 do it on one condition. You let me run blood work on you. McCALEB But that takes hours.

dialogues.speaker: DR. FOX
dialogues.text: Yes or no? McCALEB Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR SCREEN 78
dialogues.text: A grainy silver and black image of McCaleb’s heart. The snaking line of a scope moves toward it.  79 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a gurney, head in a brace, McCaleb closes his eyes as the line enters his heart. Dr. Marcus guides the line through an incision in McCaleb’s neck. McCaleb looks over at Graciella who tries to hide her distress at the sight.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: I want you to stop, McCaleb. McCALEB Stop what?

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: Everything. I was wrong to bring this to you. McCALEB No. McCaleb winces as the doctor finishes. Removing the scope, he tapes a compress to McCaleb’s neck. The doctor unstraps the brace, steps away. McCaleb looks at Graciella. McCALEB I got a new heart. But it didn’t feel like a new life.

dialogues.speaker: GRACIELLA
dialogues.text: (steps forward) I don’t know what you mean. McCaleb waits a beat for the doctor to leave. McCALEB I’ve been doing this work a long time. And it took something from me.
